üéôOn the latest episode of The Decibel, @kellygrant1 chats with @menakarw about her reporting on the tough decision facing Nunavut's elders and their families when they need round-the-clock care. 

https://t.co/FjwbtWqkeG

https://t.co/YLa0n3oEDF

"The difference here really, is that for Joe and Peepeelee and the rest of Joe's extended family, the choice was about whether or not to send him to a place that's 2000 kilometers away from home."
https://t.co/tjZwoznKo6 https://t.co/MpIhyP23NI

"It's like people anywhere in Canada who face the choice of whether or not to keep trying to care for a loved one at home as it gets more difficult, or sending them to a long term care home," says Grant. 
https://t.co/tjZwoznKo6

That leaves families in Nunavut to make a tough decision: Keep elders at home with little help, or sending them south ‚Äì often for the rest of their lives. 
https://t.co/tjZwoznKo6

üéôIn Nunavut, seniors who need round-the-clock care are transferred to a retirement home in Ottawa. This happens because Nunavut does not have enough long-term care beds overall, and because there is no secure ward for high-needs dementia patients anywhere in the territory. https://t.co/9XAbyZZ0AA

üéô‚ÄúI spoke to several elders who were born on the land in outpost camps who grew up really living a lifestyle that's entirely different from the one they live today. And these elders are a living connection to that past,‚Äù says @kellygrant1.

Most Canadians who need around-the-clock care can find it close to home. 

But a shortage of care homes in Nunavut means Inuit elders have to move thousands of kilometres south for the same level of support.
https://t.co/NZe4CuPYof

The resulting story is a powerful, in-depth look at long-term care, and the Inuit elders who have to move to the south to get the care they need. 
https://t.co/YLa0n3oEDF

https://t.co/YLa0n3oEDF

Joe Arlooktoo once served as mayor in Kimmirut, a traditional Inuit hamlet on Baffin Island. 

Amid its hilly terrain overlooking an inlet on the Arctic Ocean, the hamlet is where he wants to grow old.

https://t.co/rRov9iJgFB

‚ÄúI had a couple of people call me and say, if you don‚Äôt come soon, I‚Äôm going to have to get a lawn mower for my hair," ‚ÄîKimberly Irwin (@haircutonwheels).

https://t.co/B9JJ8YpCMK https://t.co/DZNNq1NaxP

For Ms. Irwin, providing service to seniors is more than just giving them haircuts. A large part of her work is also to provide companionship and regularly check in with some of her clients. 

https://t.co/B9JJ8YpCMK https://t.co/UlYrFhKObm

Now, she has a phone and online booking system on the @haircutonwheels website for bedside service and also operates salons in 12 long-term care homes across the GTA. 

https://t.co/B9JJ8YpCMK https://t.co/SRUP0HqJ0R

Ms. Irwin first started the company to cater to children. But two years into the business, she started getting calls for seniors. 

‚ÄúFor moms, it was a convenience. But for seniors, it‚Äôs a necessity. Many are homebound, they have difficulty getting out."
